quizzes.title: Abandoned Wife Definition
quizzes.question: What is the minimum continuous period a husband must leave his wife for her to be legally considered an 'abandoned wife' according to the text?
options: Six months
One year
Two years
Five years
quizzes.correctAnswer: Two years
quizzes.feedback: The law defines an 'abandoned wife' as one whose husband has left her for a minimum continuous period of two years.

quizzes.title: Rights of Abandoned Wife
quizzes.question: What primary legal right does an 'abandoned wife' gain after being left by her husband for two continuous years?
options: Right to remarry immediately
Right to automatically inherit property
Right to file a petition for divorce
Right to claim citizenship elsewhere
quizzes.correctAnswer: Right to file a petition for divorce
quizzes.feedback: An abandoned wife can file a petition for divorce in the District Court if she has been abandoned by her husband for two years continuously, irrespective of her religion.

quizzes.title: Maintenance Entitlement
quizzes.question: According to the document, who is generally entitled to ask for maintenance?
options: Only divorced women
Only wives with children
Divorced women and wives without sufficient means
Any married woman
quizzes.correctAnswer: Divorced women and wives without sufficient means
quizzes.feedback: The text states that divorced women and wives who do not have enough means to maintain themselves (under Sec 125 CrPC) are entitled to ask for maintenance.

quizzes.title: Maintenance Laws
quizzes.question: What type of laws primarily govern maintenance rights for divorced women in India?
options: Criminal Laws
Civil Procedure Code
Religious Personal Laws
Constitutional Law
quizzes.correctAnswer: Religious Personal Laws
quizzes.feedback: Maintenance rights for divorced women are governed by various religious personal laws in India, such as Hindu law, Muslim Personal law, and the Indian Divorce Act for Christians.

quizzes.title: Maintenance Laws (Hindu)
quizzes.question: Which Acts grant divorced Hindu women the right to claim maintenance?
options: Muslim Women Act & Indian Divorce Act
Hindu Marriage Act & Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act
Special Marriage Act & CrPC Sec 125
Guardians and Wards Act & Dowry Prohibition Act
quizzes.correctAnswer: Hindu Marriage Act & Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act
quizzes.feedback: Under Hindu law, The Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 and the Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act, 1956 grant the right to women to claim maintenance after divorce.

quizzes.title: Maintenance Laws (Muslim)
quizzes.question: Which Act specifically governs the maintenance of divorced Muslim women mentioned in the text?
options: Hindu Marriage Act, 1955
Indian Divorce Act, 1869
Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Divorce) Act, 1986
Special Marriage Act, 1954
quizzes.correctAnswer: Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Divorce) Act, 1986
quizzes.feedback: The law governing maintenance for divorced Muslim women mentioned is the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Divorce) Act, 1986.

quizzes.title: Maintenance Laws (Christian)
quizzes.question: Under which Act can divorced Christian women claim maintenance according to the document?
options: Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act, 1956
Muslim Women Act, 1986
Indian Divorce Act, 1869
Christian Marriage Act, 1872
quizzes.correctAnswer: Indian Divorce Act, 1869
quizzes.feedback: Divorced Christian women can claim maintenance under the Indian Divorce Act, 1869.

quizzes.title: Determining Maintenance Amount
quizzes.question: How is the amount of maintenance typically decided?
options: Solely by the husband's income
Solely by the wife's needs
By mutual settlement or court order
Based on the number of children
quizzes.correctAnswer: By mutual settlement or court order
quizzes.feedback: The amount of maintenance is determined either by a mutual settlement between the husband and wife or based on an order received from the court.

quizzes.title: Non-Payment of Maintenance
quizzes.question: What recourse does a wife have if her husband fails to pay court-ordered maintenance without a valid reason?
options: She automatically forfeits the amount
She can file a criminal case against him
She must wait for the husband to pay voluntarily
She can only file another civil suit
quizzes.correctAnswer: She can file a criminal case against him
quizzes.feedback: In case of non-payment of maintenance money without sufficient cause, the wife can approach the court and file a criminal case against the husband.

quizzes.title: Husband Missing
quizzes.question: If a wife hasn't heard from her husband for a certain period and doesn't know if he's alive, after how long can she file for divorce on these grounds?
options: Two years
Five years
Seven years
Ten years
quizzes.correctAnswer: Seven years
quizzes.feedback: If a wife has been abandoned and has not heard of her husband for seven years, and doesn't know if he is alive, she can file a divorce petition.

quizzes.title: Definition of Child
quizzes.question: According to the provided text, what are the legal age limits that define a 'child' for the purposes of marriage law?
options: Male under 18, Female under 18
Male under 21, Female under 21
Male under 21, Female under 18
Male under 18, Female under 16
quizzes.correctAnswer: Male under 21, Female under 18
quizzes.feedback: The law defines a child as a male person under 21 years of age and a female under 18 years of age.

quizzes.title: Child Marriage Definition
quizzes.question: What constitutes a 'child marriage' as defined in the document?
options: A marriage where both parties are under 18
A marriage arranged by parents without the children's consent
A marriage to which either of the parties is a child (below legal age)
A marriage not registered with the government
quizzes.correctAnswer: A marriage to which either of the parties is a child (below legal age)
quizzes.feedback: Child marriage is defined as a marriage where either the male (under 21) or the female (under 18), or both, are children.

quizzes.title: Punishment for Child Marriage
quizzes.question: Who can be punished for the offence of conducting or abetting a child marriage?
options: Only the parents of the child
Only the adult spouse (if one exists)
Only the priest or official performing the ceremony
Any person who performs, conducts, directs, or abets the marriage
quizzes.correctAnswer: Any person who performs, conducts, directs, or abets the marriage
quizzes.feedback: The law states that any person involved in performing, conducting, directing, or abetting a child marriage is punishable.

quizzes.title: Filing a Complaint
quizzes.question: Who is eligible to file a complaint if they suspect a child marriage is taking place?
options: Only the child involved
Only a Child Marriage Prohibition Officer
Only law enforcement officials
Any person who believes or has information about it
quizzes.correctAnswer: Any person who believes or has information about it
quizzes.feedback: A complaint can be filed by any person (e.g., teachers, doctors, parents, NGOs, neighbors) who believes or knows a child marriage is occurring.

quizzes.title: Void vs. Voidable Marriage
quizzes.question: What is the primary difference between a 'void' and a 'voidable' marriage according to the text?
options: Void marriages involve children, voidable marriages involve adults
Void marriages are illegal internationally, voidable ones only locally
A void marriage is invalid from the start; a voidable marriage is valid until terminated
Void marriages require court termination, voidable ones do not
quizzes.correctAnswer: A void marriage is invalid from the start; a voidable marriage is valid until terminated
quizzes.feedback: A void marriage is considered never to have existed legally. A voidable marriage is legally recognized unless and until a spouse decides to terminate it through legal procedure.

quizzes.title: Conditions for Void Child Marriage
quizzes.question: Under which circumstance described is a child marriage considered 'void' (invalid from the beginning)?
options: If the parents disapprove of the marriage
If the marriage is not registered within 30 days
If the child was sold for the purpose of marriage or trafficked
If the marriage took place without a religious ceremony
quizzes.correctAnswer: If the child was sold for the purpose of marriage or trafficked
quizzes.feedback: A child marriage is void if the child was taken without guardian permission, compelled, sold for marriage, or subsequently sold/trafficked/used for immoral purposes.

quizzes.title: Terminating Child Marriage
quizzes.question: Who has the legal right to file a petition to annul (terminate) a child marriage?
options: Either spouse, regardless of their age at marriage
Only the parents or guardians of the child spouse
The spouse who was a child at the time of the marriage
Only the Child Marriage Prohibition Officer
quizzes.correctAnswer: The spouse who was a child at the time of the marriage
quizzes.feedback: The petition for annulment can be filed by the spouse who was underage at the time the marriage occurred.

quizzes.title: Minor Filing for Annulment
quizzes.question: Can a person who is still a minor file a petition to annul their child marriage?
options: No, they must wait until they reach the age of majority (18 or 21)
Yes, but only if both parents consent
Yes, through their guardian or next friend along with the Child Marriage Prohibition Officer
No, only the adult spouse can file for annulment
quizzes.correctAnswer: Yes, through their guardian or next friend along with the Child Marriage Prohibition Officer
quizzes.feedback: A minor can file the petition for annulment through a guardian or next friend, accompanied by the Child Marriage Prohibition Officer.

quizzes.title: Age Limit for Annulment Petition
quizzes.question: What is the time limit for the person (who was a child at marriage) to file the annulment petition after becoming an adult?
options: Within one year of reaching adulthood
Any time before completing two years as an adult (i.e., before age 20)
Within five years of the marriage date
There is no time limit
quizzes.correctAnswer: Any time before completing two years as an adult (i.e., before age 20)
quizzes.feedback: The petition must be filed before the child completes two years as an adult, specified as reaching 20 years of age in the text.

quizzes.title: Where to File Complaint
quizzes.question: Where can a person file a complaint regarding a child marriage?
options: Only at the High Court
Only with a Non-Governmental Organization (NGO)
With the CMPO, nearest police station, or Judicial Magistrate of the First Class
Only directly to the District Collector
quizzes.correctAnswer: With the CMPO, nearest police station, or Judicial Magistrate of the First Class
quizzes.feedback: Complaints can be filed with the Child Marriage Prohibition Officer, the nearest police station, or the Judicial Magistrate of the First Class.

quizzes.title: Role of CMPO
quizzes.question: What is the primary function of a Child Marriage Prohibition Officer (CMPO)?
options: To officiate marriages
To provide marriage counseling
To prevent child marriages from occurring
To grant divorces in cases of child marriage
quizzes.correctAnswer: To prevent child marriages from occurring
quizzes.feedback: The CMPO is appointed by the State Government specifically to prevent child marriages.

quizzes.title: Annulment Procedure
quizzes.question: How can a person who was a child at the time of marriage get it legally annulled?
options: By signing a declaration with their parents
By informing the local village council
By approaching the District Court for a decree of nullity
By agreement with the other spouse recorded by police
quizzes.correctAnswer: By approaching the District Court for a decree of nullity
quizzes.feedback: To annul a child marriage, the person must approach the District Court to pass a decree of nullity.

quizzes.title: CMPO Administrative Levels
quizzes.question: Based on the examples for Kadapa and Chittoor, at which administrative levels are CMPOs typically designated?
options: Only at the State capital level
Only Village level officials
District, Divisional, Mandal, and Village levels
Only District and State levels
quizzes.correctAnswer: District, Divisional, Mandal, and Village levels
quizzes.feedback: The examples show CMPOs designated at multiple levels: District (Collector), Divisional (RDO), Mandal (Tahsildar), and Village (ICDS/Panchayat Secretaries).

quizzes.title: Definition of Child Sexual Abuse
quizzes.question: Which of the following acts can constitute child sexual abuse according to the document?
options: Only penetrative sexual assault
Only physical touching
Showing pornographic videos, stalking, or verbal abuse with sexual intent
Only acts committed by adults
quizzes.correctAnswer: Showing pornographic videos, stalking, or verbal abuse with sexual intent
quizzes.feedback: Child sexual abuse encompasses a wide range of acts including sexual harassment, rape, assault, showing pornography, using a child in pornography, verbal abuse, lewd gestures, sexualized games, stalking, and sexualized online chat.

quizzes.title: Definition of Child (POCSO)
quizzes.question: Under the Prevention of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act mentioned, who is defined as a 'child'?
options: Any person below the age of 16
Only females below the age of 18
Any person below the age of 18 years
Any person below the age of 21
quizzes.correctAnswer: Any person below the age of 18 years
quizzes.feedback: Under the POCSO Act, a 'child' is defined as any person below the age of 18 years. The Act is gender-neutral.

quizzes.title: Child Consent
quizzes.question: What is the legal standing of a child's consent to sexual activity according to the text?
options: Consent is valid if the child is above 16
Consent is valid if given freely without coercion
Consent from a child is not legally recognized
Consent is only invalid if the other person is an adult
quizzes.correctAnswer: Consent from a child is not legally recognized
quizzes.feedback: Indian law, including POCSO, does not recognize consensual sexual acts involving a child (under 18), either with another child or an adult. Consent is not a valid defense.

quizzes.title: Signs of Abuse
quizzes.question: Which of the following is listed as a potential behavioral sign that a child might be experiencing sexual abuse?
options: Sudden improvement in academic performance
Increased outgoing behavior and seeking attention
Regressive behavior such as bed wetting or thumb sucking
Strong attachment to a specific new adult
quizzes.correctAnswer: Regressive behavior such as bed wetting or thumb sucking
quizzes.feedback: The text lists several signs, including unexpected behavioral changes like social withdrawal, aggression, and regressive behaviors (e.g., bed wetting, thumb sucking).

quizzes.title: Responding to Disclosure
quizzes.question: If a child reports sexual abuse to you, what is one recommended immediate action?
options: Confront the alleged abuser directly
Wait a few days to see if the child mentions it again
Call CHILDLINE at 1098
Post about it on social media to warn others
quizzes.correctAnswer: Call CHILDLINE at 1098
quizzes.feedback: The document advises several steps, including listening patiently, raising concerns with those close to the child, calling CHILDLINE (1098), ensuring medical examination, and reporting to the police.

quizzes.title: Offenders of Child Sexual Abuse
quizzes.question: Who can be considered an offender under the laws described for child sexual abuse?
options: Only adults over 21 years old
Only strangers to the child
Any person (including another child) who commits the act, helps, or fails to report
Only family members
quizzes.correctAnswer: Any person (including another child) who commits the act, helps, or fails to report
quizzes.feedback: Offenders include any person committing the abuse (irrespective of age), anyone who helps the offender, anyone who fails to report the offense, and police officers who fail to record the complaint.

quizzes.title: Medical Emergency Procedure
quizzes.question: If a child victim needs urgent medical care, what should the police arrange according to the text?
options: Wait for the court's permission
Take the child to the nearest hospital/medical facility within 24 hours
Provide first aid at the police station
Ask the parents to arrange medical care themselves
quizzes.correctAnswer: Take the child to the nearest hospital/medical facility within 24 hours
quizzes.feedback: The police should arrange to take the child to the nearest hospital or medical care facility for emergency medical care within 24 hours of receiving information about the crime.

quizzes.title: Medical Examination Requirement
quizzes.question: Does the medical examination of a child victim depend on whether an FIR or complaint has been registered?
options: Yes, an FIR must be filed first
Yes, but only a preliminary check is done before FIR
No, the medical examination should be conducted irrespective of FIR registration
No, but parental consent is needed instead of an FIR
quizzes.correctAnswer: No, the medical examination should be conducted irrespective of FIR registration
quizzes.feedback: The medical examination of the child should be conducted regardless of whether an FIR or complaint has been registered. For a girl child, it should be done by a woman doctor.

quizzes.title: Where to File Complaint
quizzes.question: Where can a complaint regarding child sexual abuse be filed?
options: Only at the High Court
Only with the Child Welfare Committee
At the Special Juvenile Police Unit or the local police station
Only through CHILDLINE
quizzes.correctAnswer: At the Special Juvenile Police Unit or the local police station
quizzes.feedback: A complaint should be filed either with the Special Juvenile Police Unit (SJPU) or the local police.

quizzes.title: Police Refusal to File Complaint
quizzes.question: Can a police officer legally refuse to file a complaint of child sexual abuse?
options: Yes, if they believe the complaint is false
Yes, if the child does not have visible injuries
No, failure to record the crime is a punishable offense
No, but they can delay it pending investigation
quizzes.correctAnswer: No, failure to record the crime is a punishable offense
quizzes.feedback: Police officers cannot refuse to file a complaint. Failure to record such a crime is itself a crime punishable by jail term and/or fine.

quizzes.title: Role of CWC
quizzes.question: What is one key role of the Child Welfare Committee (CWC) mentioned in the document?
options: To prosecute the offender in court
To provide a 'Support Person' to assist the child
To conduct the medical examination
To directly arrest the accused
quizzes.correctAnswer: To provide a 'Support Person' to assist the child
quizzes.feedback: The CWC provides a 'Support Person' to assist the child through investigation and trial, ensures long-term rehabilitation, and can make decisions about the child's custody and placement.

quizzes.title: Recording Child's Statement
quizzes.question: Who records the statement of the child victim, and where should it ideally happen?
options: Only the Magistrate at the court
The parents at home
The police officer or Magistrate, preferably at the child's residence or chosen place
A social worker at the police station
quizzes.correctAnswer: The police officer or Magistrate, preferably at the child's residence or chosen place
quizzes.feedback: The statement is recorded by a police officer or Magistrate, ideally at the place where the child resides or another place of the child's preference, not necessarily the police station.

quizzes.title: Liability for False Information
quizzes.question: What happens if a person reports suspected child abuse in good faith, but the information later turns out to be false?
options: They face criminal charges for false reporting
They face civil liability for defamation
The law imposes no criminal or civil liability for information given in good faith
They receive a warning from the police
quizzes.correctAnswer: The law imposes no criminal or civil liability for information given in good faith
quizzes.feedback: The law protects individuals who report suspected abuse in good faith, imposing no criminal or civil liability even if the information is later found to be false.

quizzes.title: Special Courts
quizzes.question: What are 'Special Courts' in the context of child sexual abuse cases?
options: Courts exclusively for juvenile offenders
Family courts dealing with custody
Sessions Courts designated by the State Government for speedy trials
Mobile courts that travel to villages
quizzes.correctAnswer: Sessions Courts designated by the State Government for speedy trials
quizzes.feedback: Special Courts are Sessions Courts designated by State Governments specifically to ensure speedy trials for offenses under acts like POCSO.

quizzes.title: Services for Victims
quizzes.question: Which legal service is mentioned as being available to the child victim's family or guardian?
options: Reimbursement for travel expenses
Assistance of a legal counsel of their choice (Free Legal Counsel)
Compensation for emotional distress paid by the state
Mandatory mediation sessions with the offender
quizzes.correctAnswer: Assistance of a legal counsel of their choice (Free Legal Counsel)
quizzes.feedback: The family or guardian is entitled to the assistance of a legal counsel of their choice, implying access to free legal aid if needed.

quizzes.title: Victim Confidentiality
quizzes.question: What is the rule regarding the media and the identity of a child victim of sexual abuse?
options: Media can publish details if parents consent
Media must secure the identity and privacy; publishing identifying details is a crime
Media can publish names but not photos
Media only needs to protect identity until the trial begins
quizzes.correctAnswer: Media must secure the identity and privacy; publishing identifying details is a crime
quizzes.feedback: The media is legally obligated to protect the child victim's identity and privacy. Disclosing or publishing identifying information (name, address, school, etc.) is a punishable offense.

quizzes.title: CHILDLINE Helpline
quizzes.question: What is the nationwide helpline number for children in distress mentioned in the document?
quizzes.feedback: CHILDLINE, a helpline for children in need of care and protection, can be reached by dialing 1098.

quizzes.title: Definition of Sexual Harassment
quizzes.question: Which act constitutes 'sexual harassment' of a child according to the text?
options: Any form of physical penetration
Only verbal abuse without sexual intent
Repeatedly following or contacting a child with sexual intent
Failing to report an observed incident
quizzes.correctAnswer: Repeatedly following or contacting a child with sexual intent
quizzes.feedback: Sexual harassment includes acts with sexual connotations, making a child exhibit their body, showing pornographic material, repeatedly following/watching/contacting the child (stalking), or enticing for pornographic purposes.

quizzes.title: Definition of Sexual Assault
quizzes.question: How is 'sexual assault' primarily differentiated from 'penetrative sexual assault' in the text?
options: Sexual assault involves words, penetrative assault involves actions
Sexual assault is committed by minors, penetrative assault by adults
Sexual assault involves physical acts without penetration
Sexual assault requires consent, penetrative assault does not
quizzes.correctAnswer: Sexual assault involves physical acts without penetration
quizzes.feedback: Sexual assault is defined as acts of a physical nature *without* penetration (e.g., stalking, showing dirty pictures, touching private parts).

quizzes.title: Definition of Penetrative Sexual Assault
quizzes.question: What constitutes 'penetrative sexual assault'?
options: Showing pornographic pictures
Stalking a child online
Any form of penetration into private parts or application of mouth to private parts
Making lewd gestures
quizzes.correctAnswer: Any form of penetration into private parts or application of mouth to private parts
quizzes.feedback: Penetrative sexual assault involves any form of penetration (e.g., into vagina, urethra, anus, mouth) or applying the mouth to private parts, or forcing the child to penetrate someone else.

quizzes.title: Gang Penetrative Sexual Assault
quizzes.question: When is an act considered 'gang penetrative sexual assault'?
options: Any sexual assault committed outdoors
When multiple children are assaulted simultaneously
When a child is sexually assaulted by one or more persons acting together
When the assault involves crossing state lines
quizzes.correctAnswer: When a child is sexually assaulted by one or more persons acting together
quizzes.feedback: It occurs when a child is subjected to sexual assault by one or more persons of a group acting in furtherance of a common intention.

quizzes.title: Reporting Process Flowchart
quizzes.question: According to the flowchart, what is the first step in the process after an incident occurs?
options: Recording statement by Magistrate
Medical Examination
Reporting the incident to local police / Special Juvenile Police Unit
Taking the child to a shelter home

quizzes.feedback: The flowchart begins with 'Reporting the incident to local police/ Special Juvenile Police Unit'.

quizzes.title: Reporting Process Flowchart
quizzes.question: Within what timeframe should the Special Juvenile Police Unit or Police record the initial statement, as per the flowchart?
options: Immediately
Within 24 hours
Within 48 hours
Within one week
quizzes.correctAnswer: Within 24 hours
quizzes.feedback: The second step in the flowchart indicates 'Recording of statement by Special Juvenile Police Unit or the Police within 24 hours'.

quizzes.title: Reporting Process Flowchart
quizzes.question: The flowchart specifies that if a medical examination is needed, who should ideally conduct it?
options: Any available doctor
A police officer
A Female Doctor
A child psychologist
quizzes.correctAnswer: A Female Doctor
quizzes.feedback: The flowchart branch indicates taking the child 'For Medical Examination by Female Doctor'.

quizzes.title: Reporting Process Flowchart
quizzes.question: What is the target timeframe for the Special Court (Child Friendly) to complete the trial, according to the flowchart?
options: Within six months
Within one year
Within two years
As soon as possible
quizzes.correctAnswer: Within one year
quizzes.feedback: The final step shown in the flowchart states 'Special Court (Child Friendly) shall complete trial within one year'.

quizzes.title: Definition of Abatement
quizzes.question: What does 'abatement' mean in the context of child sexual offenses?
options: Reducing the severity of the crime
The act of committing the crime itself
Intentionally instigating, aiding, or being part of a conspiracy to commit the offense
Reporting the crime after it has occurred
quizzes.correctAnswer: Intentionally instigating, aiding, or being part of a conspiracy to commit the offense
quizzes.feedback: Abatement involves intentionally instigating, aiding (by act or illegal omission), or conspiring with others to commit the offense.

quizzes.title: SJPU/Police Role in Child Protection
quizzes.question: If the police or SJPU believe a child needs care and protection, what action should they take?
options: Send the child home with a warning
Wait for the CWC's instructions
Admit the child to a shelter home or hospital and report to CWC/Special Court
Conduct their own investigation before taking action
quizzes.correctAnswer: Admit the child to a shelter home or hospital and report to CWC/Special Court
quizzes.feedback: If the SJPU or local police believe the child needs care and protection, they should record reasons and admit the child to a shelter home or hospital, reporting the matter immediately to the CWC and Special Court.

quizzes.title: Definition of Online Abuse
quizzes.question: According to the document, which of the following constitutes online abuse?
options: Receiving spam emails
Forgetting your password
Creating fake accounts or sharing embarrassing videos of someone
Disagreeing with someone in an online forum
quizzes.correctAnswer: Creating fake accounts or sharing embarrassing videos of someone
quizzes.feedback: Online abuse includes threatening messages, creating/sharing embarrassing images/videos, fake accounts, identity theft, and sexually explicit messages, often occurring on social media, chat platforms, or forums.

quizzes.title: Action Against Online Abuse
quizzes.question: What are the two main actions suggested in the document when facing online abuse?
options: Ignore the abuser and block them
Engage with the abuser publicly and change your password
Report to the platform administrator and file an FIR with the police
Delete your account and contact a lawyer
quizzes.correctAnswer: Report to the platform administrator and file an FIR with the police
quizzes.feedback: The document suggests checking the platform's policy to request action from the administrator and filing an FIR (First Information Report) at a police station.

quizzes.title: Unauthorized Account Access
quizzes.question: What legal offense is committed if someone accesses your online account without permission?
options: Identity Theft
Violation of Privacy
Unauthorized Access (Sec 43(a) IT Act)
Criminal Intimidation
quizzes.correctAnswer: Unauthorized Access (Sec 43(a) IT Act)
quizzes.feedback: Accessing someone's account without permission constitutes the offense of unauthorized access under Section 43(a) of the Information Technology Act.

quizzes.title: Penalty for Unauthorized Access
quizzes.question: What is the potential penalty for unauthorized access to someone's online account under the IT Act?
options: A fine up to Rs 1 lakh
Imprisonment up to 1 year
Damages by compensation not exceeding one crore rupees
Community service
quizzes.correctAnswer: Damages by compensation not exceeding one crore rupees
quizzes.feedback: An offender guilty of unauthorized access under Section 43(a) of the IT Act is liable to pay damages by way of compensation, potentially up to one crore rupees, to the affected person.

quizzes.title: Identity Theft Definition
quizzes.question: What action constitutes 'identity theft' as described in the document?
options: Forgetting your own password
Using a common password across multiple sites
Dishonestly stealing someone's password or unique identifying feature
Sharing your account details with a friend
quizzes.correctAnswer: Dishonestly stealing someone's password or unique identifying feature
quizzes.feedback: Identity theft involves dishonestly stealing someone's password, electronic signature, or other unique identifying feature.

quizzes.title: Reporting Identity Theft
quizzes.question: How can you report identity theft according to the text?
options: By posting about it online
By contacting the website administrator only
By filing a criminal complaint in a police station
By changing your password immediately
quizzes.correctAnswer: By filing a criminal complaint in a police station
quizzes.feedback: To report identity theft, you can file a criminal complaint at a police station.

quizzes.title: Circulating Private Pictures (IT Act)
quizzes.question: What is the legal consequence under the IT Act (Sec 66E) for sharing private pictures of someone without consent?
options: A warning from the platform
Violation of privacy, punishable by imprisonment up to three years or fine up to two lakh rupees or both
Account suspension only
Mandatory public apology
quizzes.correctAnswer: Violation of privacy, punishable by imprisonment up to three years or fine up to two lakh rupees or both
quizzes.feedback: Taking, sharing, or publishing private pictures without consent is a violation of privacy under Section 66E of the IT Act, punishable with imprisonment up to three years, a fine up to two lakh rupees, or both.

quizzes.title: Voyeurism (IPC)
quizzes.question: Under the Indian Penal Code (Sec 354C), what offense is committed by taking/circulating pictures of a woman in a private act without her knowledge?
options: Defamation
Unauthorized Access
Voyeurism
Criminal Intimidation
quizzes.correctAnswer: Voyeurism
quizzes.feedback: Taking and/or circulating pictures of a woman engaged in private acts without her knowledge is the offense of voyeurism under Section 354C of the Indian Penal Code.

quizzes.title: Obscene Material Online
quizzes.question: Is publishing or sharing obscene or sexually explicit material online considered a crime according to the document?
options: No, it's protected free speech
Yes, but only if the victim is female
Yes, it is a crime punishable under law, applicable to victims of any gender
Only if it involves minors
quizzes.correctAnswer: Yes, it is a crime punishable under law, applicable to victims of any gender
quizzes.feedback: Yes, publishing and sharing obscene or sexually explicit material online is a crime under information technology law, and the victims can be male or female.

quizzes.title: Online Threats (Criminal Intimidation)
quizzes.question: If someone threatens to kill you, hurt you, or destroy your property online, what offense might they be committing under the IPC?
options: Cyberstalking
Defamation
Criminal Intimidation (Sec 503 IPC)

quizzes.title: Arrest Procedure in DV Cases
